elements.content: The synthesis, structures, and properties of five new coordination polymers containing bis-pyridyl-bis-amide and polycarboxylate ligands, {[Cd­(1,2-bdc)­(L 1 )­(H2O)]·H2O} n [1,2-H2bdc = benzene-1,2-dicarboxylic acid; L 1 = N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide] (1), {[Cd2(1,3-bdc)2(L 1 )3]·8H2O} n [1,3-H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid] (2), [Cd­(1,4-bdc)­(L 1 )­(H2O)2] n [1,4-H2bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid] (3), {[Cd2(1,2,3-Hbtc)2(L 1 )3]·4H2O} n [1,2,3-H3btc = 1,2,3-benzene-tricarboxylic acid] (4), and [Cd­(1,4-pda)­(L 2 )] n [L 2 = N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­adipoamide; 1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid] (5), are reported, which have been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 forms a looplike 1D chain, whereas 2 and 4 show 3D frameworks with a new self-catenated net with point symbol (65·8). Complex 3 displays a 2D layer with the sql topology and 5 displays a rare 8T17 self-catenated net. The dimensionality and structural types of 1–3 can be adjusted by varying the ligand isomerism of the dicarboxylate ligands.

Complex 1 forms a looplike 1D chain, whereas 2 and 4 show 3D frameworks with a new self-catenated net with point symbol (65⋅8). Complex 3 displays a 2D layer with the sql topology and 5 displays a rare 8T17 self-catenated net. The dimensionality and structural types of 1-3 can be adjusted by varying the ligand isomerism of the dicarboxylate ligands.

elements.content:
By manipulation of the isomeric effect of the dicarboxylate ligands, self-catenated coordination polymers incorporating the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands can be expected.

Introduction

The design and synthesis of new coordination polymers with controlled dimensionality have become the center of interests in the chemical and material communities. These complexes thus prepared have attracted great attention due to not only their intriguing topological features but also their potential applications in the areas such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, and magnetism. Judicial choice of spacer ligand with diverse functionalities and metal-ion template may lead to well-defined coordination polymers. Although enormous examples of interesting coordination polymers have been reported, the control of structural diversity remains a challenge in the field of crystal engineering and the influential factors are less ascertained. Self-catenated nets are single nets that exhibit the peculiar feature of containing shortest rings through which pass other components of the same network. Catenation can be identified by the presence of edge(s) that thread a ring; in other words, they share at least one point with a disc-like film bounded by the ring.

Introduction

The design and synthesis of new coordination polymers with controlled dimensionality have become the center of interests in the chemical and material communities. These complexes thus prepared have attracted great attention due to not only their intriguing topological features but also their potential applications in the areas such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, and magnetism. Judicial choice of spacer ligand with diverse functionalities and metal-ion template may lead to well-defined coordination polymers. Although enormous examples of interesting coordination polymers have been reported, the control of structural diversity remains a challenge in the field of crystal engineering and the influential factors are less ascertained. Self-catenated nets are single nets that exhibit the peculiar feature of containing shortest rings through which pass other components of the same network. Catenation can be identified by the presence of edge(s) that thread a ring; in other words, they share at least one point with a disc-like film bounded by the ring.

elements.content: The mixed-ligand assembly system is an important strategy for the generation of new coordination polymers. We have reported a series of coordination polymers based on the isomeric N,N′-di­(2-pyridyl)­adipoamide, N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­adipoamide, and N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)­adipoamide and benzenedicarboxylate ligands. The structural diversity of these Zn­(II) and Cd­(II) coordination polymers are subject to the changes of the donor atom positions of the spacer ligands, leading to the formation of a series of coordination polymers involving a 3D self-catenated net of {424·5·63}-ilc topology. Recently, we have also reported that reactions of the flexible N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L 1 ) with Cu­(II) salts in the presence of the isomeric phenylenediacetic acids under hydrothermal conditions afforded {[Cu­(L 1 )­(1,2-pda)]·H2O} n (1,2-H2pda = 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid), {[Cu­(L 1 )­(1,3-pda)]·2H2O}n (1,3-H2pda = 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid), and {[Cu­(L 1 )­(1,4-pda)]·2H2O} n , which form a single 3,5-coordinated 3D net with the (42·65·83)­(42·6)-3,5T1 topology, a 5-fold interpenetrated 3D structure with the (65·8)-cds topology, and the first 1D self-catenated coordination polymer, respectively. The ligand isomerism of the phenylenediacetate ligands was found to be important in determining the structural types. Obviously, by manipulation of the isomeric effect from the bis-pyridyl-bis-amide or dicarboxylate ligand, self-catenated coordination polymers can be achieved.

Recently, we have also reported that reactions of the flexible N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (L  1 ) with Cu(II) salts in the presence of the isomeric phenylenediacetic acids under hydrothermal conditions afforded {[Cu(L  1 )(1,2-pda)]⋅H2O} n  (1,2-H2pda = 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid), {[Cu(L  1 )(1,3-pda)]⋅2H2O}n (1,3-H2pda = 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid), and {[Cu(L  1 )(1,4-pda)]⋅2H2O} n , which form a single 3,5-coordinated 3D net with the (42⋅65⋅83)(42⋅6)-3,5T1 topology, a 5-fold interpenetrated 3D structure with the (65⋅8)-cds topology, and the first 1D self-catenated coordination polymer, respectively. The ligand isomerism of the phenylenediacetate ligands was found to be important in determining the structural types. Obviously, by manipulation of the isomeric effect from the bis-pyridyl-bis-amide or dicarboxylate ligand, self-catenated coordination polymers can be achieved.

elements.content: As our continuing efforts to investigate the correlation between the mixed-ligand system and the structural diversity of novel coordination polymers, we sought to investigate the structure-directing roles of the spacer ligands on the construction of bis-pyridyl-bis-amide-based Cd­(II) coordination polymers by changing their donor atom positions and flexibility. The syntheses, crystal structures, and thermal and luminescent properties of {[Cd­(1,2-bdc)­(L 1 )­(H2O)]·H2O} n [1,2-H2bdc = benzene-1,2-dicarboxylic acid; L 1 = N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide] (1), {[Cd2(1,3-bdc)2(L 1 )3]·8H2O} n [1,3-H2bdc = benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid] (2), [Cd­(1,4-bdc)­(L 1 )­(H2O)2] n [1,4-H2bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid] (3), {[Cd2(1,2,3-Hbtc)2(L 1 )3]·4H2O} n [1,2,3-H3btc = 1,2,3-benzene-tricarboxylic acid] (4), and [Cd­(1,4-pda)­(L 2 )]+n [L 2 = N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­adipoamide] (5) form the subject of this report.

elements.content: Elemental analyses were performed on a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O or an Elementar Vario EL cube analyzer. IR spectra (KBr disk) were obtained from a JASCO FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) measurements were carried out on a TG/DTA 6200 analyzer. Emission spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out using a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer with Cu Kα (λα = 1.54 Å) radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Elemental analyses were performed on a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O or an Elementar Vario EL cube analyzer. IR spectra (KBr disk) were obtained from a JASCO FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) measurements were carried out on a TG/DTA 6200 analyzer. Emission spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction was carried out using a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer with Cu Kα (λα = 1.54 Å) radiation.

elements.content: The reagents CdBr2·4H2O, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2bdc), and benzene-1,2,3-tricarboxylic acid (1,2,3-H3btc) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co., Cd­(CH3COO)2·2H2O was purchased from Alfa Aesar, and 1,4-phenylenediacetic acids were purchased from ACROS Co. The ligands N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L 1 ) and N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­adipoamide (L 2 ) were prepared according to published procedures.

Materials

The reagents CdBr2⋅4H2O, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2bdc), and benzene-1,2,3-tricarboxylic acid (1,2,3-H3btc) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co., Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O was purchased from Alfa Aesar, and 1,4-phenylenediacetic acids were purchased from ACROS Co. The ligands N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (L  1 ) and N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)adipoamide (L  2 ) were prepared according to published procedures.

The diffraction data for complexes 1–5 were collected on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer at 22 °C, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λα = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was carried out by standard methods with use of well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. An empirical absorption correction based on “multi-scan” was applied to the data for these complexes. The positions of some of the heavier atoms were located by the direct or Patterson method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-squares refinements. All the hydrogen atoms of complexes 1–5 were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 5.10. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in . Specified hydrogen bonds (with esds except fixed and riding H) for 1–5 are listed in Tables S1–S5, respectively.

X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data for complexes 1-5 were collected on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer at 22 °C, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λα = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was carried out by standard methods with use of well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. An empirical absorption correction based on "multi-scan" was applied to the data for these complexes. The positions of some of the heavier atoms were located by the direct or Patterson method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-squares refinements. All the hydrogen atoms of complexes 1-5 were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 5.10. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in . Specified hydrogen bonds (with esds except fixed and riding H) for 1-5 are listed in Tables S1-S5, respectively.

a shows the coordination environment of Cd­(II) ion, which is coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two L 1 ligands [Cd–N = 2.293(2) and 2.337(3) Å], four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,2-bdc2– ligands [Cd–O = 2.335(2)–2.644(2) Å], and one oxygen atom of a water molecule [Cd–O = 2.359(2) Å], resulting in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. b shows that the Cd­(II) ions are bridged by the 1,2-bdc2– ligands to form dinuclear units, which are linked by the L 1 ligands to form 1D looped chains, as shown in c. The Cd···Cd distances that are bridged by 1,2-bdc2– and L 1 are 5.11 and 18.46 Å, respectively. The 1D looped chains are interlinked through the N–H···O [H···O = 1.97 Å; ∠N–H···O = 171.5°] hydrogen bonds to the carboxylate oxygen atoms to form a 2D supramolecular layer. Noticeably, the larger rings of the looped chain are supported by the N–H···O [H···O = 2.17 Å; ∠N–H···O = 159.4°] hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms, while the smaller rings are supported by the O–H···O [H···O = 1.90 and 2.31 Å; ∠O–H···O = 162.2° and 145.3°] hydrogen bonds from the coordinated water molecules to the carboxylate oxygen atoms, Figure S1.

Results and Discussion

Structure of 1 

 a shows the coordination environment of Cd(II) ion, which is coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two L  1  ligands [Cd-N = 2.293(2) and 2.337(3) Å], four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,2-bdc2- ligands [Cd-O = 2.335(2)-2.644(2) Å], and one oxygen atom of a water molecule [Cd-O = 2.359(2) Å], resulting in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. b shows that the Cd(II) ions are bridged by the 1,2-bdc2- ligands to form dinuclear units, which are linked by the L  1  ligands to form 1D looped chains, as shown in c. The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances that are bridged by 1,2-bdc2- and L  1  are 5.11 and 18.46 Å, respectively. The 1D looped chains are interlinked through the N-H⋅⋅⋅O [H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.97 Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 171.5°] hydrogen bonds to the carboxylate oxygen atoms to form a 2D supramolecular layer. Noticeably, the larger rings of the looped chain are supported by the N-H⋅⋅⋅O [H⋅⋅⋅O = 2.17 Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 159.4°] hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms, while the smaller rings are supported by the O-H⋅⋅⋅O [H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.90 and 2.31 Å; ∠O-H⋅⋅⋅O = 162.2° and 145.3°] hydrogen bonds from the coordinated water molecules to the carboxylate oxygen atoms, Figure S1.

elements.content: The coordination environments about the Cd­(II) ions are shown in a,b for 2 and 4, respectively. The metal ions exhibit distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with two nitrogen atoms apical and one equatorial, and the left four equatorial positions are occupied by two chelating carboxylates. This same local metal coordination results in the same underlying net even if the two structures are not isomorphous but have similar cell axis and angles (total cell volume differs by 1% only) The extra carboxylic acid group in the ligands (1,2,3-Hbtc2– vs 1,3-bdc2–) remains uncoordinated. In detail, the Cd­(II) metal centers of 2 are coordinated by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms from three L 1 ligands [Cd(1)-N = 2.341(3)–2.435(3) Å; Cd(2)–N = 2.365(3)–2.384(3) Å] and four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,3-bdc2– ligands [Cd(1)–O = 2.310(2)–2.522(2) Å; Cd(2)–O = 2.293(2)–2.403(2) Å]. Similarly each of the Cd­(II) ions of 4 is coordinated by three pyridyl nitrogen atoms from three L 1 ligands [Cd–N = 2.376(4)–2.439(4) Å] and four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands [Cd–O = 2.353(3)–2.516(4) Å], resulting also in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The Cd­(II) ions in 2 and 4 are also singly and doubly bridged by the L 1 ligands in an alternate fashion and singly bridged by the 1,3-bdc2– and 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands, respectively, resulting in isoreticular 3D coordination networks. The Cd···Cd distances that are bridged by 1,3-bdc2– and L 1 are 10.05–10.08 and 19.67–22.01 Å, respectively, and those that are bridged by 1,2,3-Hbtc2– and L 1 ligands are 9.59 and 19.63–21.40 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The 3D framework of 2 is supported by the N–H···O hydrogen bonds to the water oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.92–2.38 Å; ∠N–H···O = 117.1–169.0°] and carbonyl oxygen atoms [H···O = 2.20 Å; ∠N–H···O = 173.1°], while O–H···O hydrogen bonds from water molecules to water molecules [H···O = 1.86–2.18 Å; ∠O–H···O = 122.7–175.4°], carboxylate oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.85–1.93 Å; ∠O–H···O = 162.7–175.3°], and carbonyl oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.88–2.18 Å; ∠O–H···O = 135.5–172.2°] are also observed, Figure S2. Similarly, the 3D framework of 4 is supported by the N–H···O hydrogen bonds to the water oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.97 and 2.08 Å; ∠N–H···O = 169.8° and 151.6°] and O–H···O hydrogen bonds from water molecules to carboxylate oxygen atoms [H···O = 2.04–2.33 Å; ∠O–H···O = 120.9–174.4°], Figure S3. Moreover, O–H···O hydrogen bonds from the uncoordinated carboxylic groups of 4 to the carbonyl oxygen atoms [H···O = 2.28 Å; ∠O–H···O = 124.6°] and carboxylate oxygen atoms [H···O = 2.29 Å; ∠O–H···O = 112.7°] are also observed.

elements.content: If the Cd­(II) ions of 2 and 4 are regarded as 4-connected nodes and the two-connected L 1 , 1,3-bdc2– and 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands, are simplified as linkers, the two structures are isoreticular, and they have the same underlying net: a new uninodal 4-connected self-catenated 3D net with the (65·8) topology, c, with the vertex symbol [6·6·6·6·62·1012], determined using ToposPro. A careful analysis of the net shows that it can be formed by cross-linking sets of parallel stacking of 5-fold interpenetrated hcb layers (see Figure S4). The layers stack AAA normal to the longest axes (>22 Å, [001] for 2 and [100] for 4) and are pillared by L 1 ligands. Self-catenated nets that arise from a subset of interpenetrated nets are known, while the net observed here is the first example from cross-link of interpenetrated 2D nets. As highlighted in d, each shortest six-membered ring is catenated by four rods of the same network. The result indicates that the uncoordinated carboxylic acid group of 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligand between 2 and 4 has no effect on the overall topology.

elements.content: a shows the coordination environment of the Cd­(II) ion, which is coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms form two L 1 ligands [Cd–N = 2.351(2) Å], four oxygen atoms from two 1,4-bdc2– ligands [Cd–O = 2.280(1) Å], and two water molecules [Cd–O = 2.331(1) Å] to form a distorted octahedral geometry. b shows that the Cd­(II) ions are bridged by the L 1 and 1,4-bdc2– ligands to form 2D layers, and c depicts its schematic drawing with the sql topology. The Cd···Cd distances that are bridged by 1,4-bdc2– and L 1 are 11.76 and 19.99 Å, respectively. The 2D layers are interlinked through the N–H···O [H···O = 2.17 Å; ∠N–H···O = 153.7°] hydrogen bonds to the carboxylate oxygen atoms and O–H···O hydrogen bonds from water molecules to the carboxylate oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.93 Å; ∠O–H···O = 148.1°] and carbonyl oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.98 Å; ∠O–H···O = 151.7°] to form a 3D supramolecular structure, Figure S5.

elements.content: Crystals of 5 conform to the triclinic space group P1̅ with one Cd­(II) cation, two halves of two L 2 ligands lying about inversion centers, and two halves of two 1,4-pda2– anions that also lie about inversion centers in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environments of the dinuclear Cd­(II) metal centers. Each of the Cd­(II) ions is seven-coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two L 2 ligands [Cd–N = 2.293(2) and 2.375(1) Å] and five oxygen atoms from three 1,4-pda2– ligands [Cd–O = 2.252(1)–2.560 (1) Å], resulting in a distorted pentagonal–bipyramidal geometry. The Cd­(II) ions are linked together by the 1,4-pda2– ligands that adopt the μ2-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 coordination mode to form 2D layers, b, which are further connected by the 1,4-pda2– ligands that adopt the μ4-κ2,κ1,κ2,κ1 coordination mode and the L 2 ligands to afford a 3D structure. The 3D framework is supported by the N–H···O hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.98 Å; ∠N–H···O = 169.3°] and carboxylate oxygen atoms [H···O = 1.94 Å; ∠N–H···O = 171.3°], Figure S6.

Each of the Cd(II) ions is seven-coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two L  2  ligands [Cd-N = 2.293(2) and 2.375(1) Å] and five oxygen atoms from three 1,4-pda2- ligands [Cd-O = 2.252(1)-2.560 (1) Å], resulting in a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The Cd(II) ions are linked together by the 1,4-pda2- ligands that adopt the μ2-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 coordination mode to form 2D layers, b, which are further connected by the 1,4-pda2- ligands that adopt the μ4-κ2,κ1,κ2,κ1 coordination mode and the L  2  ligands to afford a 3D structure. The 3D framework is supported by the N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds to the carbonyl oxygen atoms [H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.98 Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 169.3°] and carboxylate oxygen atoms [H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.94 Å; ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 171.3°], Figure S6.

elements.content: If the Cd2(μ-COO)2 dimeric units are taken as structural building units (SBUs) and defined as nodes, the structure of 5 can be simplified as a 8-coordinated net with a rare self-catenated (424·64)-8T17 topology, c. The self-catenation could be seen as cross-linking of the 2D 44-sql nets pillared by rods. As highlighted in d, each shortest four-membered ring is catenated by two rods of the same network. Notwithstanding the self-catenation of strong 4-rings, the net 8T17 has a tiling: the essential rings are not catenated, a phenomena already known for example for the 5-c net fnu, see Figure S7. The 8T17 net has been observed in two coordination networks containing similar long and short ligands and dimeric (Cd2) or trimeric (Zn3) SBUs, as shown in {Cd­(1,4-bdc)­[1,4-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene]·nH2O} n , and [Zn3(1,4-bdc)3(1,4-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethoxy)­benzene)] n , respectively.

elements.content: Although the self-catenated coordination polymers have been the subject of studies during recent years, those that involve bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands remain scarcely reported. While {[Cu­(L 1 )­(1,4-pda)]·2H2O} n (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid) is the first 1D self-catenated coordination polymer, the complex [Co3­(1,4-bdc)­3­(L3)] n (L3 = N,N′-bis­(3-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide) forms a unique self-catenated 3D net with the (36·410·511·6)-8T53 topology (with catenation of 6-rings), and {[Cd2(1,4-bdc)2(L 2 )2]·3H2O3} n exhibits self-catenated 3D net of {424·5·63}-ilc topology (with self-catenation of 4-rings with four other 4-rings).
elements.clean_text:
Self-Catenation Involving Bis-pyridyl-bis-amide Ligands

Although the self-catenated coordination polymers have been the subject of studies during recent years, those that involve bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands remain scarcely reported. While {[Cu(L  1 )(1,4-pda)]⋅2H2O} n  (1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid) is the first 1D self-catenated coordination polymer, the complex [Co3(1,4-bdc)3(L3)] n  (L3 = N,N'-bis(3-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide) forms a unique self-catenated 3D net with the (36⋅410⋅511⋅6)-8T53 topology (with catenation of 6-rings), and {[Cd2(1,4-bdc)2(L  2 )2]⋅3H2O3} n  exhibits self-catenated 3D net of {424⋅5⋅63}-ilc topology (with self-catenation of 4-rings with four other 4-rings).

elements.content: The L 1 and L 2 can be arranged in A and G conformations, which are given when the C–C–C–C torsion angle (θ) is 180° ≥ θ > 90° and 0° ≤ θ ≤ 90°, respectively, and based on the relative orientation of the CO (or N–H) groups, each conformation can adopts cis or trans arrangement. Due to the difference in the orientations of the pyridyl nitrogen atom positions, three more orientations, anti-anti, syn-anti, and syn-syn, are possible for the ligand. Based on this descriptor, the ligand conformations of complexes 1–5 are assigned and listed in . Noticeably, to show the unique self-catenation mode of (65·8) topology, the L 1 ligands in 2 and 4 adopt three and two different ligand conformations, respectively, which are rarely observed for the bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands. Moreover, all the skeleton carbon atoms of the L 1 ligands of 2 and 4 adopt the AAAAA conformation. The various ligand conformations indicate that L 1 and L 2 ligands are sufficiently flexible to adjust to the stereochemical requirements for the formation of the complexes 1–5, which adopts the conformation that maximize their intra- and intermolecular forces.
elements.clean_text:
Conformations and Bonding Modes of the Ligands

The L  1  and L  2  can be arranged in A and G conformations, which are given when the C-C-C-C torsion angle (θ) is 180° ≥ θ > 90° and 0° ≤ θ ≤ 90°, respectively, and based on the relative orientation of the CO (or N-H) groups, each conformation can adopts cis or trans arrangement. Due to the difference in the orientations of the pyridyl nitrogen atom positions, three more orientations, anti-anti, syn-anti, and syn-syn, are possible for the ligand. Based on this descriptor, the ligand conformations of complexes 1-5 are assigned and listed in . Noticeably, to show the unique self-catenation mode of (65⋅8) topology, the L  1  ligands in 2 and 4 adopt three and two different ligand conformations, respectively, which are rarely observed for the bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands. Moreover, all the skeleton carbon atoms of the L  1  ligands of 2 and 4 adopt the AAAAA conformation. The various ligand conformations indicate that L  1  and L  2  ligands are sufficiently flexible to adjust to the stereochemical requirements for the formation of the complexes 1-5, which adopts the conformation that maximize their intra- and intermolecular forces.

Various bonding modes are observed for the polycarboxylate ligands in 1–5, . Both of the 1,2-bdc2– and 1,3-bdc2– ligands in 1 and 2 chelate the metal centers through all four carboxylate oxygen atoms, adopting the μ2-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 mode. While the 1,4-bdc2– ligand 3 bridges two metal centers through one of the oxygen atoms of each carboxylate group that displays the μ2-κ1,κ0,κ1,κ0 mode, the 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands of 4 adopt the μ2-κ1,κ1,κ0,κ0,κ1,κ1 bonding mode. Noticeably, the 1,4-pda2– ligands of 5 show two types of bonding modes of μ2-κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1 and μ4-κ2,κ1,κ2,κ1, resulting in a rare self-catenated (424·64)-8T17 topology.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal decomposition of 1–5. The samples were heated in nitrogen gas at a pressure of 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 and finished at 900 °C, Figures S8–S12 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows that a total weight loss of 4.65% occurred between 30 and 180 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 75.97% at 240–560 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,2-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.26%). For complex 2, a total weight loss of 8.39% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 9.11%). The weight loss of 76.55% occurring between 280 and 800 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,3-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.64%). For complex 3, a total weight loss of 6.32% occurred between 30 and 220 °C, presumably due to the removal of the coordinated H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 73.42% at 280–600 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,4-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.26%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that a total weight loss of 4.76% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 4.25%). The weight loss of 83.58% at 200–900 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands (calcd 82.61%). For complex 5, the TGA curve shows the gradual weight loss of 79.07% at 290–800 °C, which is due to the decomposition of the L 2 and 1,4-pda2– ligands (calculated 78.70%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Gravimetric Analyses

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal decomposition of 1-5. The samples were heated in nitrogen gas at a pressure of 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 and finished at 900 °C, Figures S8-S12 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows that a total weight loss of 4.65% occurred between 30 and 180 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 75.97% at 240-560 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,2-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.26%). For complex 2, a total weight loss of 8.39% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 9.11%). The weight loss of 76.55% occurring between 280 and 800 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,3-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.64%). For complex 3, a total weight loss of 6.32% occurred between 30 and 220 °C, presumably due to the removal of the coordinated H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 73.42% at 280-600 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,4-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.26%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that a total weight loss of 4.76% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 4.25%). The weight loss of 83.58% at 200-900 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,2,3-Hbtc2- ligands (calcd 82.61%). For complex 5, the TGA curve shows the gradual weight loss of 79.07% at 290-800 °C, which is due to the decomposition of the L  2  and 1,4-pda2- ligands (calculated 78.70%).

The TGA results show that the weight losses that are due to the removal of cocrystallized and bonded water molecules occurring at 30–220 °C, and the organic ligands decomposed at temperatures above 200 °C. Noticeably, there is an 80 °C difference in decomposing the organic ligands between 2 and 4 that adopt the same self-catenation mode, which may be due to the different polycarboxylate ligands that result in different supramolecular interactions.

Noticeably, there is an 80 °C difference in decomposing the organic ligands between 2 and 4 that adopt the same self-catenation mode, which may be due to the different polycarboxylate ligands that result in different supramolecular interactions.

elements.content: The emission spectra of the free organic ligands and complexes 1–5 were measured in the solid state at room temperature, Figures S13–S24 and . The L 1 , L 2 , and poly­(carboxylic acid)­s show emissions in the range 315–450 nm, which may be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand (IL) n → π* or π → π* transitions. The red and blue shifts with respect to the organic ligands observed for complexes 1–5 are most probably due to the different ligand conformations and coordination modes adopted by the organic ligands and the formation of different structural types. Noticeably, the red-shift of the emission wavelength of 4 with respect to the corresponding poly­(carboxylic acid) is significantly larger than that of 2, indicating that the uncoordinated carboxylic groups that result in multiple O–H···O hydrogen bonds may play important roles in determining the luminescent properties. It has been shown that hydrogen bonding changes the electron density distributions of the complex, and thus the luminescent properties could be controlled by tuning the hydrogen bonding. Since the Cd­(II) ions are hardly oxidized or reduced, it is not probable to assume that the emissions of 1–5 are due to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). These emissions can most probably be attributed to intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of the free organic ligands and complexes 1-5 were measured in the solid state at room temperature, Figures S13-S24 and . The L  1 , L  2 , and poly(carboxylic acid)s show emissions in the range 315-450 nm, which may be tentatively ascribed to the intraligand (IL) n → π* or π → π* transitions. The red and blue shifts with respect to the organic ligands observed for complexes 1-5 are most probably due to the different ligand conformations and coordination modes adopted by the organic ligands and the formation of different structural types. Noticeably, the red-shift of the emission wavelength of 4 with respect to the corresponding poly(carboxylic acid) is significantly larger than that of 2, indicating that the uncoordinated carboxylic groups that result in multiple O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds may play important roles in determining the luminescent properties. It has been shown that hydrogen bonding changes the electron density distributions of the complex, and thus the luminescent properties could be controlled by tuning the hydrogen bonding. Since the Cd(II) ions are hardly oxidized or reduced, it is not probable to assume that the emissions of 1-5 are due to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). These emissions can most probably be attributed to intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT).

Five new Cd­(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, which show 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. The structures of complexes 1–3 are directed by the isomeric 1,2-, 1,3-, and 1,4-bdc2– ligands, forming a looplike 1D chain, a novel 3D self-catenated coordination network with the (65·8) topology, and a 2D layer with the sql topology, respectively. While complex 4 is isoreticular to 2, complex 5 displays a rare 8T17 self-catenated net. We have shown that the uncoordinated carboxylic acid group of 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligand has no effect on the structural diversity of 2 and 4, but it plays important roles in determining the thermal and luminescent properties. We have also further verified that by manipulation of the isomeric effect of the dicarboxylate ligands, self-catenated coordination polymers incorporating the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands can be expected.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Five new Cd(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, which show 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. The structures of complexes 1-3 are directed by the isomeric 1,2-, 1,3-, and 1,4-bdc2- ligands, forming a looplike 1D chain, a novel 3D self-catenated coordination network with the (65⋅8) topology, and a 2D layer with the sql topology, respectively. While complex 4 is isoreticular to 2, complex 5 displays a rare 8T17 self-catenated net. We have shown that the uncoordinated carboxylic acid group of 1,2,3-Hbtc2- ligand has no effect on the structural diversity of 2 and 4, but it plays important roles in determining the thermal and luminescent properties. We have also further verified that by manipulation of the isomeric effect of the dicarboxylate ligands, self-catenated coordination polymers incorporating the flexible bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands can be expected.

Slow cooling of the reaction system afforded colorless crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction. Yield: 0.034 g (52%). Anal. cln_elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal decomposition of 1–5. The samples were heated in nitrogen gas at a pressure of 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 and finished at 900 °C, Figures S8–S12 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows that a total weight loss of 4.65% occurred between 30 and 180 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 75.97% at 240–560 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,2-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.26%). For complex 2, a total weight loss of 8.39% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 9.11%). The weight loss of 76.55% occurring between 280 and 800 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,3-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.64%). For complex 3, a total weight loss of 6.32% occurred between 30 and 220 °C, presumably due to the removal of the coordinated H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 73.42% at 280–600 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,4-bdc2– ligands (calcd 74.26%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that a total weight loss of 4.76% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 4.25%). The weight loss of 83.58% at 200–900 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L 1 and 1,2,3-Hbtc2– ligands (calcd 82.61%). For complex 5, the TGA curve shows the gradual weight loss of 79.07% at 290–800 °C, which is due to the decomposition of the L 2 and 1,4-pda2– ligands (calculated 78.70%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Gravimetric Analyses

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal decomposition of 1-5. The samples were heated in nitrogen gas at a pressure of 1 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 and finished at 900 °C, Figures S8-S12 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows that a total weight loss of 4.65% occurred between 30 and 180 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 75.97% at 240-560 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,2-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.26%). For complex 2, a total weight loss of 8.39% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 9.11%). The weight loss of 76.55% occurring between 280 and 800 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,3-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.64%). For complex 3, a total weight loss of 6.32% occurred between 30 and 220 °C, presumably due to the removal of the coordinated H2O (calcd 5.64%). The weight loss of 73.42% at 280-600 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,4-bdc2- ligands (calcd 74.26%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that a total weight loss of 4.76% occurred between 30 and 200 °C, presumably due to the removal of the cocrystallized H2O (calcd 4.25%). The weight loss of 83.58% at 200-900 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of the L  1  and 1,2,3-Hbtc2- ligands (calcd 82.61%). For complex 5, the TGA curve shows the gradual weight loss of 79.07% at 290-800 °C, which is due to the decomposition of the L  2  and 1,4-pda2- ligands (calculated 78.70%).
